an F story last October Mark spindel a
59 year old elementary school principal
from New Jersey had a biopsy that showed
cancer in his prostate gland when I was
first told that I did have cancer my
heart fell down to my feet I became very
uncertain as to how advanced it was will
I be a survivor prostate cancer is an
extremely complicated area of Medicine
increasingly experts are questioning
whether it is being properly treated
indeed a diagnosis of prostate cancer
can be confusing because there are so
many treatment options the three main
forms widely available for prostate
cancer patients are active surveillance
radiation therapy and surgery you hear
of other people having prostate cancer
but you don't think that it could ever
happen to you and now you really have to
reach out and find the necessary
elements of what you're going to do next
treatment options vary based on the
stage and grade of the cancer marks
tumor was discovered early it had not
spread outside the prostate gland he
chose a robotic assisted radical
prostatectomy his doctor is ashta woori
at Cornell Medical Center New York
Presbyterian Hospital I understand what
you're going through and it's not easy
the tests show that it is self contained
that's right it's an early cancer is it
actually that is my main concern the
factor that there will be incontinence
and impotence is on the back burner but
that is also a concern of mine and when
will that come back to me once we get on
the cancer out the next priority is
under urine control and that makes a
difference because that'll have an
impact on your quality of life patients
differ in terms of their sexual function
before surgery patients differ in terms
of what kind of in tumor they have
patients also differ in terms of their
age patients differ what kind of a
medication they are taking and patients
differ in terms of their body weight and
the price
sighs these all things can ultimately
impact what kind of impossibilities for
recovery of sexual function they have
okay seven days after his preoperative
meeting with dr. Tiwari Mark and his
family arrived for the early morning
surgery anything specific in your mind
no I'm just worried about the outcome
that it is self-contained I'm a little
bit nervous about the next couple of
days you know it needs a little he needs
a little bit of TLC and some some care
but I understand it's fairly easy and
we'll get through it before we embark
upon doing a robotic we have to have a
very clear-cut plan as to what we want
to do we use a specialized bias
information to kind of create a map this
MRI scan is also available in the real
time so that we can cross refer while we
are doing the surgery that where exactly
the tumor is if it is visible during
surgery dr. Tiwari sits at a master
operating console and uses two finger
control joysticks to manipulate a camera
and surgical instruments attached to a
patient side robotic cart removing the
cancerous prostate gland is the number
one goal of the surgery dr. Tiwari must
also be careful not to damage the
muscles and nerves involved in urinary
and erectile functions instead of
touching the nerves we kind of
delicately tease prostate away from
those doves we were always very
conscious that the look for any telltale
signs of cancer trying to come to the
surface and which was not in his case
they were his area on the left side I
was little concerned it was showing his
significant bulge and that is the area
where actually his cancer was but i
think we stayed in a decent safe playing
around that area within 24 hours after
the surgery mark is out of his bed and
walking in the recovery area how much
have you bro
probably about three quarters of a mile
that's it I'm just waiting for the test
results to come back which I'm anxious
about other than that I feel fine fine
let's go home right now dr. tiwari
discharges mark from the hospital later
that morning they meet again seven days
later when Mark returned to the Brady
urologic center to get his catheter
removed and to receive news of his
pathology report let me just kind of
give you all the details it looks like
you have negative margins negative lymph
nodes negative seminal vesicles and
bottom line- here is good so it's
everything is God hard cancer on the
side where I was seeing that bulge but
it looks like that the margins are
negative so so that's really important
this is the best pathology report we can
get but that's the moment of truth every
time I look at the pathology report out
nervous a patient's nervous six weeks
after surgery mark is walking three
miles a day with his wife Jane at a
local community center walking is an
important aspect in the recovery of
prostate cancer surgery as it helps
patients to regain urinary continence by
strengthening the muscles of the pelvic
floor at home mark is getting back into
the routine of things and is eagerly
looking forward to returning to work
still he must avoid heavy lifting which
could lead to a hernia at the incision
sites as they heal I have no problems
with incontinence whatsoever during the
first week the problem was basically
corrected and very lucky to say so the
other aspect with the sexual functions
I'm getting right back on track with
that and basically on average where
everybody should be at this time the
biggest surprise probably
the need for a another individual to
really take care of you especially for
that first week the emptying of the
catheter bag the sleepless nights
because of sleeping on on one's back the
difficulty in walking well I think in
some ways it's made us closer you know
we spent a lot of time working things
out and trying to help them feel better
and you know but I think it's time he's
gotten back to work there's a cliche
that live each day the most because you
never know what tomorrow brings and I
guess I've started to do that because
you never know what tomorrow will bring
